news_header: The UK government has reached a new funding deal with Drax power station to reduce subsidies and emissions, while ensuring wood pellets are sustainably sourced.
news_original_title: Subsidies halved for controversial Drax power station
news_text: The UK government has agreed on a new funding arrangement with the Drax power station, which will cut subsidies in half and ensure that 100% of the wood pellets burned are sustainably sourced. Drax, a controversial wood-burning power station, generates about 5% of the UK's electricity but has faced criticism for its CO2 emissions. The new deal will run from 2027 to 2031, allowing Drax to serve as a backup to cheaper renewable sources. The government predicts a reduction in subsidies from nearly £1 billion to £470 million. Critics, including Greenpeace, have called the deal a compromise but hope it will limit Drax's operations. Drax claims the new arrangement will save consumers money and help balance the electricity system.
